title: Sentence Structure and Punctuation
introduction: Understanding sentence structure and using proper punctuation are essential for clear communication in written English.

content.value: Contains one independent clause. Example: She reads books.
Contains two independent clauses joined by a conjunction. Example: She reads books, and she watches movies.
Contains one independent clause and one dependent clause. Example: She reads books because she enjoys learning.
Ends a statement. Example: She is reading.
Separates elements in a list or clauses. Example: I bought apples, bananas, and oranges.
Connects two closely related independent clauses. Example: She writes; She reads.
Introduces a list or explanation. Example: She loves three things: books, music, and coffee.
Encloses direct speech. Example: She said, "Hello!"
Shows strong emotion. Example: Wow! That's amazing!
Ends a question. Example: Where are you going?

exercises.title: Sentence Structure Identification
exercises.instructions: Identify whether each sentence is simple, compound, or complex.

questions.question: The dog barked loudly, and the cat ran away.
The dog barked loudly because it saw a stranger.

exercises.title: Punctuation Practice
exercises.instructions: Add the correct punctuation to the following sentences.

questions.question: The students brought notebooks pencils and textbooks
questions.answer: The students brought notebooks, pencils, and textbooks.

questions.question: She said I will be there at 8 oclock
questions.answer: She said, "I will be there at 8 o'clock."
